document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Acylophorus Nordmann, 1837 from Madagascar and Mascarene Islands (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Staphylininae: Acylophorina)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Acylophorus Nordmann, 1837 from Madagascar and Mascarene Islands (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Staphylininae: Acylophorina)

bibRefCitation.refString: Jarrige, J. (1965) Les Acylophorus malgaches (Col. Staphylinidae). Bullettin de la Societ entomologique de France, 70, 139 - 143.

Madagascar , Tananarive [ Antananarivo ], ca. 18 54' S , 47 31' E .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–8.
Acylophorus tristis Jarrige.
1, 2, 6–8 holotype; 3, 4, Col de Marotaolana; 5, Andasibe. 1, habitus; 2, forebody; 3, detail of head; 4, mandibles; 5, maxillary palpus; 6, aedeagus lateral; 7, aedeagus ventro-lateral; 8, aedeagus ventral. 6–8, same scale bars.

FIGURES 9–17.
Acylophorus tristis Jarrige.
9, 10, 15–17, Col de Marotaolana; 11–13, Sendrisoa; 14, Manindray. 9, metatarsus lateral; 10, metatarsus dorsal; 11, 16, aedeagus lateral; 12, aedeagus ventro-lateral; 13–15, aedeagus ventral. ES, empodial setae. 16, 17, transmitted light. 9–10, 11–17, same scale bars.

FIGURES 18–21.
Acylophorus tristis Jarrige, Col de Marotaolana.
18, male tergites 9, 10; 19, male sternite 9; 20, female tergites 9, 10; 21, valves.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription (n=10). Body length 6.9–8.7 mm (M= 7.9 mm , HT= 7.8 mm ), forebody length 3.2–4.0 mm (M= 3.7 mm , HT= 3.7 mm ) ( Fig. 1 ). Body black, abdominal tergites at most slightly iridescent; antennae brownish black with base of first two segments and segments 3–4 reddish; legs reddish brown, tarsi and maxillary palpi reddish.

Male (n=6). Sternite 9 long and narrow ( Fig. 19 ), apex of tergite 10 rounded with very long apical setae ( Fig. 18 ). Aedeagus ( Figs. 6–8 , 11–17 ) 0.91–0.97 mm long (M= 0.93 mm , HT= 0.92 mm ). Parameres bilobed, lobes widely separated, sensory pegs confusedly arranged right at apex ( Fig 17 ). Median lobe of aedeagus markedly overreaching paramere, apex broadly rounded ( Figs. 8 , 13–15, 17 ).
Female. Tergite 10 with apicolateral emarginations, sharply pointed ( Fig. 20 ), valves as in Fig. 21 .

Differential diagnosis.
Acylophorus tristis
differs from all hirtherto known Afrotropical species of
A. densipennis
group by the median lobe markedly overreaching the paramere, and by widely separated lobes of the paramere.
Distribution . The species is distributed in East, Central , South-East and West-Madagascar ( Fig. 172 ).
